feelingNow.value: I feel overwhelmed but trying to stay hopeful and informed about my options

intro_letter_body.value:
Dear Sarah,

We know receiving a cancer diagnosis can feel overwhelming. The good news is that you're taking an important step by seeking information and understanding your diagnosis. Knowledge empowers you to make informed decisions alongside your medical team.

This report breaks down your specific diagnosis, test results, and treatment options in clear language. We've organized everything to help you feel more confident as you move forward.

With care and respect,
Your Defiant Health Team
care@defianthealth.com

cancer_type.explanation: Most common type of breast cancer, starting in milk ducts and spreading to surrounding tissue.

location_of_tumors.value: Left breast, upper outer quadrant (2 o'clock position)
location_of_tumors.explanation: The location of a breast tumor is important to help your medical team assess the likelihood of lymph node involvement and guide surgical treatment.

size.explanation: The size of the tumor is important in guiding treatment. Different sized tumors may require different approaches. Additionally, knowing the initial size allows doctors to compare images taken after treatment to determine whether the tumor has shrunk or is responding to treatment.

stage.explanation: Locally advanced breast cancer with lymph node involvement.

stage_type.explanation: Stage determined by physical exam and imaging before surgery or treatment begins.

overall_grade.explanation: A grade 3 (out of 3) from the Nottingham grading system indicates rapidly growing cells that look very different from normal cells.

er_status.explanation: Estrogen receptor positive means cancer cells have receptors for estrogen hormone.

pr_status.explanation: Progesterone receptor negative means cancer cells do not have receptors for progesterone.

her2_status.explanation: HER2-positive breast cancer has high levels of HER2 protein, which promotes cancer growth. These cancers tend to grow faster but can be treated with targeted HER2 therapies.

ihc_result.explanation: IHC (immunohistochemistry) score of 3+ indicates strong HER2 protein overexpression.

fish_ish_result.explanation: FISH test confirms HER2 gene amplification, supporting HER2-positive status.

brca_status.explanation: Harmful BRCA1 mutation detected, increasing risk for breast and ovarian cancers.

n_category.explanation: Cancer spread to 4-9 axillary lymph nodes.

pdl1_cps_score.explanation: PD-L1 expression is high (CPS ≥10), suggesting potential benefit from immunotherapy.

tnbc_status.explanation: Not triple-negative breast cancer - hormone receptor positive and HER2 positive.

ibc_status.explanation: No evidence of inflammatory breast cancer - no skin changes or rapid breast swelling observed.

cancer_type.explanation: Most common type of breast cancer, starting in milk ducts and spreading to surrounding tissue.

location_of_tumor.value: Left breast, upper outer quadrant (2 o'clock position)
location_of_tumor.explanation: The location of a breast tumor is important to help your medical team assess the likelihood of lymph node involvement and guide surgical treatment.

stage.explanation: Locally advanced breast cancer with lymph node involvement.

stage_type.explanation: Stage determined by physical exam and imaging before surgery or treatment begins.

size.explanation: The size of the tumor is important in guiding treatment. Different sized tumors may require different approaches.

overall_grade.explanation: A grade 3 (out of 3) from the Nottingham grading system indicates rapidly growing cells that look very different from normal cells.

tubule_formation_score.explanation: Score of 3 indicates minimal tubule formation (poorly differentiated).

nuclear_pleomorphism_score.explanation: Score of 3 indicates marked variation in nuclear size and shape.

mitotic_count_score.explanation: Score of 3 indicates high mitotic activity (rapidly dividing cells).

er_status.explanation: 95% of tumor cells show estrogen receptor positivity.

pr_status.explanation: Only 5% of tumor cells show progesterone receptor positivity.

her2_status.explanation: HER2-positive breast cancer has high levels of HER2 protein, which promotes cancer growth. These cancers can be treated with targeted HER2 therapies.

ihc_result.explanation: IHC score of 3+ indicates strong HER2 protein overexpression.

fish_ish_result.explanation: FISH test confirms HER2 gene amplification.

tests_sources.label: tests_sources
tests_sources.value: Imaging Report - Memorial Medical Center.pdf, Pathology Report - Memorial Medical Center.pdf, Genetic Testing - GeneDx Laboratory.pdf, Biomarker Testing - Memorial Medical Center.pdf

tests.explanation: A screening mammogram is an X-ray of the breast used to detect breast cancer early in women who have no signs or symptoms of the disease.
A diagnostic mammogram is a more detailed X-ray of the breast used to investigate suspicious changes found on a screening mammogram.
This test uses sound waves to create pictures of the inside of the breast. It helps distinguish between fluid-filled cysts and solid masses.
A breast MRI uses magnets to take very detailed pictures of the breast. Often used to evaluate extent of cancer and check the other breast.

tests.test_name: CT scan of chest, abdomen, pelvis and Bone scan
tests.explanation: CT scan creates detailed pictures to check if breast cancer has spread to other parts of the body such as lungs, liver, or bones.
A PET/CT combines imaging with detection of active cancer cells using radioactive sugar. Helps detect cancer spread throughout the body.
Ultrasound of the heart to check heart function before starting chemotherapy that may affect the heart.
Test determines if breast cancer cells have receptors for estrogen hormone. ER-positive cancers can be treated with hormone therapy.
Test determines if breast cancer cells have receptors for progesterone hormone.
Test measures HER2 protein on cancer cells. HER2-positive cancers can be treated with targeted HER2 therapies like trastuzumab.
Test checks if tumor expresses PD-L1 protein. High levels may indicate potential benefit from immunotherapy treatments.

tests.patient_facing_label: Oncotype DX Recurrence Score: Not performed (HER2+)
tests.explanation: Genomic test typically not needed for HER2-positive breast cancers as treatment is guided by HER2 status.

tests.test_name: Germline genetic testing including breast cancer mutations
tests.explanation: Testing found inherited BRCA1 gene mutation which increases risk of breast and ovarian cancers.

tests.test_name: Blood test: CBC, CMP, TSH, Hep B
tests.explanation: Routine blood tests to check blood counts, organ function before starting treatment.

tests.test_name: List other tests completed not otherwise covered in this list above
tests.patient_facing_label: Core needle biopsy of left breast mass
tests.explanation: Procedure to remove tissue sample from breast for pathology testing.
Meeting with fertility specialist to discuss egg/embryo freezing options before chemotherapy.
Met with genetic counselor to discuss BRCA1 results and family implications.
Met with medical oncologist to discuss chemotherapy and targeted therapy options.
Consultation with breast surgeon to discuss surgical options after neoadjuvant chemotherapy.
Will meet with radiation oncologist after surgery to discuss radiation therapy.

records_reviewed.notes: Initial screening detected abnormality in left breast.
Confirmed invasive ductal carcinoma, HER2 positive.
Evaluated tumor extent and ruled out additional lesions.
Discussed BRCA1 results and family screening.
Treatment plan discussion - neoadjuvant chemotherapy with HER2 targeted therapy.

treatments.table_description: For HER2-positive breast cancer, chemotherapy combined with HER2-targeted drugs is highly effective at shrinking tumors and preventing recurrence.
treatments.column_2_value: Heart monitoring required, possible infusion reactions, diarrhea
treatments.column_3_value: Usually given every 3 weeks for 1 year total

treatments.table_description: For HER2-positive breast cancer, chemotherapy combined with HER2-targeted drugs is highly effective at shrinking tumors and preventing recurrence.
treatments.column_2_value: Nausea, fatigue, hair loss, low blood counts, heart monitoring needed

treatments.table_description: For HER2-positive breast cancer, chemotherapy combined with HER2-targeted drugs is highly effective at shrinking tumors and preventing recurrence.
treatments.column_1_value: Paclitaxel (Taxol) or Docetaxel (Taxotere) - Given after AC with HER2 drugs
treatments.column_2_value: Numbness/tingling in hands/feet, hair loss, muscle aches, allergic reactions
treatments.column_3_value: Usually 12 weekly doses or 4 doses every 3 weeks

treatments.table_description: Since your cancer is estrogen receptor positive, hormone-blocking therapy will be recommended after chemotherapy to reduce recurrence risk.
treatments.column_2_value: Hot flashes, vaginal discharge, small blood clot risk

treatments.table_description: Since your cancer is estrogen receptor positive, hormone-blocking therapy will be recommended after chemotherapy to reduce recurrence risk.
treatments.column_1_value: Ovarian suppression (goserelin/leuprolide) + Aromatase inhibitor - May be recommended given BRCA1 status
treatments.column_2_value: Hot flashes, joint pain, bone thinning, menopausal symptoms
treatments.column_3_value: Monthly injections for 5 years + daily AI pill

treatments.table_description: Surgery will typically be performed after neoadjuvant chemotherapy to remove remaining cancer. Given BRCA1 status, bilateral mastectomy may be discussed.
treatments.column_1_value: Lumpectomy (if excellent response to chemotherapy) - Usually followed by radiation
treatments.column_2_value: Shorter recovery, breast preservation, radiation required

treatments.table_description: Surgery will typically be performed after neoadjuvant chemotherapy to remove remaining cancer. Given BRCA1 status, bilateral mastectomy may be discussed.
treatments.column_1_value: Bilateral mastectomy - May be recommended given BRCA1 mutation and future cancer risk
treatments.column_2_value: Longer recovery, removes both breasts to reduce future risk

treatments.table_description: Surgery will typically be performed after neoadjuvant chemotherapy to remove remaining cancer. Given BRCA1 status, bilateral mastectomy may be discussed.
treatments.column_1_value: Breast reconstruction (immediate or delayed) - Multiple options available
treatments.column_2_value: Additional surgery time, various recovery based on method chosen
treatments.column_3_value: Can be done at surgery or later

treatments.table_description: Radiation therapy is typically recommended after lumpectomy. May also be recommended after mastectomy for Stage IIIA with lymph node involvement.
treatments.column_1_value: Breast radiation (after lumpectomy) or chest wall radiation (after mastectomy)
treatments.column_2_value: Skin changes like sunburn, fatigue, breast firmness

treatments.table_description: Radiation therapy is typically recommended after lumpectomy. May also be recommended after mastectomy for Stage IIIA with lymph node involvement.
treatments.column_1_value: Lymph node radiation - Recommended due to multiple positive nodes
treatments.column_2_value: Similar to chest radiation plus small lymphedema risk
treatments.column_3_value: Given at same time as breast/chest radiation

diagnosis.title: HER2-Positive & Hormone Receptor Positive
diagnosis.body: Your cancer is both HER2-positive and hormone receptor positive. This means you can benefit from both HER2-targeted therapies and hormone therapy, giving you multiple effective treatment options.

diagnosis.title: BRCA1 Mutation Detected
diagnosis.body: The BRCA1 gene mutation increases your risk of breast and ovarian cancers. This is important information for your treatment decisions (such as considering bilateral mastectomy) and for your family members who may want genetic testing.

diagnosis.title: Stage IIIA Treatment Approach
diagnosis.body: Stage IIIA breast cancer is locally advanced. The typical approach is chemotherapy first (neoadjuvant) to shrink the tumor, followed by surgery, then additional treatment with targeted therapy, hormone therapy, and often radiation.

testing_and_consultations.title: Currently in: Planning Phase
testing_and_consultations.body: You've completed diagnostic and staging testing. Your care team is now finalizing your treatment plan. You may have a few more consultations and pre-treatment tests before starting therapy.

testing_and_consultations.title: Preparing for Treatment
testing_and_consultations.body: Before starting chemotherapy, you'll complete baseline tests like heart function assessment and blood work. If you're considering fertility preservation, those consultations should happen soon.

testing_and_consultations.title: Your Care Team is Ready
testing_and_consultations.body: You've met with your medical oncologist and have consultations scheduled with surgery. Your multidisciplinary team will coordinate your care throughout treatment.

treatment_planning.title: HER2-Targeted Therapy is Key
treatment_planning.body: HER2-targeted drugs like trastuzumab and pertuzumab dramatically improve outcomes for HER2-positive breast cancer. These will be a central part of your treatment plan.

treatment_planning.title: Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy First
treatment_planning.body: For Stage IIIA breast cancer, starting with chemotherapy before surgery (neoadjuvant approach) helps shrink the tumor and may allow for less extensive surgery.

treatment_planning.title: BRCA1 Considerations
treatment_planning.body: Your BRCA1 mutation is important for surgical planning. Many women with BRCA1 mutations choose bilateral mastectomy to reduce future cancer risk, but this is a personal decision to discuss with your surgeon.

items.question: With Stage IIIA HER2-positive breast cancer, what is the recommended sequence of treatments? Will I start with chemotherapy before surgery?
What HER2-targeted drugs do you recommend (trastuzumab, pertuzumab, others)? How long will I receive these medications?
What chemotherapy regimen do you recommend? What are the most common side effects I should prepare for?
Since HER2 drugs can affect the heart, how often will my heart function be monitored during treatment?
After chemotherapy, what hormone therapy do you recommend given that I'm ER-positive and premenopausal?
How does my BRCA1 mutation affect my treatment plan? Are there any BRCA-specific therapies I should consider?
Given my age and BRCA1 status, what are my options for fertility preservation? How soon do we need to do this before starting treatment?
What is the total expected timeline for my treatment from start to finish?
What medications or strategies can help manage common side effects like nausea, fatigue, and neuropathy?
When will surgery be scheduled relative to my chemotherapy? How will you assess if the chemotherapy is working?
Given my BRCA1 mutation, what are the pros and cons of lumpectomy versus unilateral versus bilateral mastectomy?
Since I have positive lymph nodes now, what lymph node surgery will I need after chemotherapy?
If I choose mastectomy, what are my reconstruction options? Can it be done at the same time as the mastectomy?
Given my BRCA1 mutation, when should I consider preventive surgery for ovarian cancer risk?
What is the typical recovery time for the surgery you're recommending? When can I return to work and normal activities?
Will I need radiation therapy after surgery? Does it matter whether I have lumpectomy or mastectomy?
Since I have multiple positive lymph nodes, will you also radiate my lymph node areas?
When will radiation start after surgery? How long will the treatment course be?
What are the short-term and long-term side effects of radiation I should know about?
